He was born in Copenhagen, where his father was pastor of the French church.
Educated at Paris and Geneva, he began his life-work in 1825 as founder and
pastor of a Protestant church in Naples, moving to Lyon in 1827. Here his
evangelical preaching, and especially a sermon on the duties of communicants
(Qui doit communier?), led to his deposition by the Catholic Minister of
education and religion. Instead of leaving Lyon he began to preach in a hall and
then in a chapel.

On 2 September 1829 he married Hannah Honyman in Lyon. They had seven children.

In 1836 he took a professorship in the theological college of Montauban,
removing in 1847 to Paris as preacher at the Oratoire. He died there in 1856.

Monod was undoubtedly the foremost Protestant preacher of 19th century France.
